As someone who has served as the Vice President of Academic Excellence of  her sorority, I can say it is true that the Greek GPA is higher than the non-Greek GPA based on the official paperwork I used to receive from the Dean (and I just left the position, so this information is current as of Spring 2013). HOWEVER, THIS DIFFERENCE IS VERY SMALL! We attend classes on a very smart campus, and we should all be proud of that. No need to bitch and whine about Greeks, non-Greeks, etc. Let's all just get along....
I served as Scholarship Chair for my sorority and I can confirm that everything Brittany said above is 100% true :)

Why? I'm not Greek, but considering there is a GPA cap to even participate in recruitment, and then specific sororities have their own GPA minimums, that alone would cut out a lot of outliers and raise the average.
I can speak off of experience.  Since joining greek life my GPA has gone up.  Why I can only guess but for whatever reason, its just one of the many things I love about being Greek.

"In fact, Black people have suffered quite a bit only about 60-70 years ago during the Civil Rights Movement." You lost your argument before it started

#1619: I hate when people say "slavery was so long ago, Black people just need to get over it." It's okay to remember the Holocaust, and we'll never forget 9/11, but we have to get over Slavery? They were all tragedies. And if my great-grandmother (who is still alive) can tell me stories about her grandmother who was born a slave, then I don't think it was that long ago.

Coming into UM, I was sheltered from knowing the true injustices blacks face in the US today. I grew up in a family where it didn't matter what color skin you were. I didn't start having or hearing provocative conversations such as this until my freshman year at UM. One girl told me that I should go learn about black oppression if I wanted to understand. And now I have been learning about it, little by little. It's been a process but I am beginning to understand the realities of the issues blacks face today, especially based on the persecution of their past. But I do just want to say this. Contemporary problems need contemporary solutions. It hurt me when I was trying to reach out to blacks at UM, and they turned me down because they thought I could never be capable of understanding. And that attitude self-perpetuates racial injustice. I would love to see more of an alliance between blacks and whites in the US, starting at a place like UM, where our student body is capable of creating this bond. I would love to hear a movement of whites and blacks discussing  Trayvon Martin, the NYC stop-and-frisk program, and black youth's unequal access to education. Thus, I can't control what my ancestors did, but I can control what I do. And if you belittle me for that, or initially judge whites for the past, when we do try to have this tough discussion about race in the present, then that's not resolving anything. Maybe your ancestors that were enslaved won't receive reparations from the government, but that doesn't mean solutions for black oppression can't be met today.

I think the OP intended "only about 60-70 years ago" to mean "as recently as 60-70 years ago," not that the sufferings and injustice occurred exclusively within that time period, as that is clearly not true (poor word choice on his/her end). S/he is also not saying racism is over and that there is no more injustice/hatred/discrimination; the OP is, I think, trying to point out that SLAVERY ITSELF was 150 years ago, so no living person can demand retribution or compensation for slavery or the atrocities committed then. No one--black, white, Asian, whatever--should forget about or get over slavery, as it was a horrible, terrible tragedy, but expecting to be given any special treatment because one's great-grandmother's grandmother was a slave is not reasonable. Asking for remedies for today's injustices is an entirely different story and is absolutely, perfectly justified. All the OP is saying is that past slavery of distant relatives is not a valid reason to expect benefits.

I believe that it's important to take advantage of the opportunities you have now and not to let past transgressions hold you back from success. But a positive mentality can only do so much. The institution of slavery and the discriminatory legislation/mindset that followed it cannot be disregarded or forgotten because it still affects African Americans today. Part of the reason many African Americans are now poor, is because our slave ancestors did not get paid and therefore had no inheritance to pass onto their children. The generations that followed them had little access to well-paying jobs, either because they did not have access to a good education or because prejudiced people simply wouldn't hire them. Now there are some people who take advantage of welfare and aren't looking for a job. But there are plenty more who started to with nothing, and because they didn't grow up in the best neighborhood and didn't go to best school (because their neighborhood doesn't feed into the 'good schools') they are struggling to make ends meet everyday and are just hoping their kids can have it better. Yes, slavery is over and it happened 'a long time ago ', but the aftermath of slavery lives on.

in my eyes black people's suffering went beyond slavery... it wasn't just happy trails after the civil war... in fact we suffer with each injustice done to us to this very day... some people think that just because obama is in office that's the end of racism WELL IT'S NOT so gtfoh

#1748: This is a response to post #1619. Yes it is true that all those things you mentioned are very sad and horrible. In fact, Black people have suffered quite a bit only about 60-70 years ago during the Civil Rights Movement. But I think the reason that people say that Black people should "get over slavery" is because some Black people believe they deserve some kind of extra benefit for their ancestors suffering. For example, the poor Black and Hispanic minorities groups in South Florida receive government aid, welfare and child support. This money comes from the taxes that the working class people have to pay. My mom is a physical therapist and she has over 20+ years of experience with working with these individuals. She has found that many of them do not use the money for the right reasons, such as buying IPhones, nice "kicks" (AKA shoes), a fancy weave/ hairdo, and other materialistic things. When my mom asks them why they are buying these things, many of them reply that their people have suffered long enough and they should finally be rewarded. Yes, your ancestors suffered from slavery, but you personally did not. It happened over 100 years ago so there is no way you went through slavery. This is unfair and a very wrong reasoning. I'm not trying to be racist, this is just the unfortunate reality that these people think this way. They bring the racism and slavery card to victimize themselves and justify why they should get better treatment. There are other ethnic groups that have suffered as well. The Jewish people lost nearly 6,000,000 of their people during the Holocaust, but rarely do hear them complaining or bringing that up. The Chinese suffered dearly during World War II when Japan invaded them. They were brutally killed, the women were raped, and they were humiliated. But no one ever mentions that, in fact I don't think many even realize that the Chinese suffered during that time. There are so many more instances throughout history that ethnic groups have been persecuted. It's important to learn from the past so we don't make the same mistake, but it also important to put the past aside, and look for a better future. We should not bring up the past to justify why we victimize ourselves. Our weaknesses is our own, we should own up to our faults and try to fix ourselves.

#1731: As a person previously opposed to study drugs, I have come to realize that, if used in moderation, they are an amazing tool during these trying times. So all of you drug haters, have fun getting C's :)
